recipes.name: Mysore Pak
ingredients: 1 cup Ghee (clarified butter), divided (3/4 cup for flour mixture, 1/4 cup for stirring)
directions: Step 1: Heat 1 teaspoon of ghee in a non-stick pan. Add the besan flour and roast over medium heat for 3-4 minutes, or until fragrant. Sift the roasted besan to remove any lumps.
Step 2: In a bowl, combine the sifted besan with 3/4 cup of ghee. Mix well and set aside for 15 minutes. The mixture should have a pouring consistency.
Step 3: Grease a plate or tray with a little ghee and set aside.

Step 4: In a non-stick pan, combine the sugar and water. Bring to a boil over medium heat and cook until the syrup reaches one-string consistency. To test this, take a small amount of syrup between your thumb and index finger; it should form a single string when separated.
Step 5: Add the besan-ghee mixture to the sugar syrup. Stir continuously.
Step 6: Gradually add the remaining 1/4 cup of ghee, a little at a time, while stirring constantly. This prevents the mixture from drying out.
Step 7: Reduce the heat to low and continue stirring. The mixture will initially stick to the pan but will eventually form a ball and pull away from the sides.
Step 8: Once the mixture is no longer sticky and forms a ball, remove from heat. Pour the mixture onto the greased plate. It will spread evenly on its own.
Step 9: While the Mysore Pak is still hot, cut it into squares or diamonds. Serve and enjoy.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of glistening, golden Mysore Pak squares arranged on a rustic brass plate. Use a dark, moody background with soft, directional lighting to highlight the porous texture and rich color.  A shallow depth of field focuses on the foreground pieces, with a few cashews scattered around.  Incorporate a small silver bowl of ghee in the background, slightly out of focus. Aim for a warm, inviting mood that evokes a sense of indulgence and tradition.

recipes.name: Mysore Pak
directions: Step 1: In a large pan or kadai, heat the ghee over medium heat. Once hot, remove 1 tablespoon of the hot ghee and add it to the besan flour. Mix well until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Set aside.

Step 2: In a separate saucepan, combine the sugar and water. Bring to a boil over medium heat and cook until the syrup reaches a one-string consistency. To test for this, take a drop of syrup between your thumb and index finger; when you gently pull them apart, a single, thin string of syrup should form.

Step 3: Once the sugar syrup reaches one-string consistency, reduce the heat to low. Gradually sprinkle the besan mixture into the sugar syrup, stirring continuously and vigorously to prevent lumps.  Simultaneously, in another pan, heat the remaining ghee and oil together over low heat.

Step 4: Continue adding the besan mixture to the syrup, ensuring it's well combined. As the mixture thickens, start adding the hot ghee and oil mixture little by little, while constantly stirring. The mixture will absorb the ghee quickly and become frothy.

Step 5: Keep stirring until the mixture thickens further, starts to leave the sides of the pan, and develops a slightly porous texture.  If it doesn't separate from the sides, cook until the desired porous consistency is achieved.  Immediately transfer the mixture to a greased plate or tray.

Step 6: Using a greased spatula or spoon, quickly flatten and spread the Mysore Pak evenly in the prepared plate. While still warm, score the Mysore Pak into desired shapes (squares or diamonds). Allow it to cool completely before breaking along the scored lines and storing in an airtight container.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of a glistening square of Mysore Pak on a rustic brass plate.  Use a shallow depth of field, focusing sharply on the foreground piece with others softly blurred behind.  Warm, directional light should highlight the porous texture and golden hue.  Garnish with a few scattered cashew halves and a drizzle of ghee.  The backdrop should be a dark, textured surface, creating a rich, indulgent mood.

recipes.name: Baby Pak Choy and Mushroom Frittata
ingredients: 1 bunch baby pak choy, trimmed and finely chopped
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 180°C (160°C fan-forced). Grease a 6cm-deep, 20cm round cake pan and line the base and sides with baking paper.
Step 2: Heat olive oil in a frying pan over medium-high heat. Add crushed garlic and sliced mushrooms. Cook, stirring, for 3-4 minutes, or until softened.
Step 3: Add chopped pak choy, trimmed beansprouts, and sliced green onions. Cook, stirring, for 1 minute, or until pak choy has wilted.
Step 4: Remove from heat. In a bowl, whisk together eggs and heavy cream. Add the cooked vegetable mixture and stir to combine.
Step 5: Pour the mixture into the prepared pan. Bake for 50-60 minutes, or until golden brown and set.
Step 6: Let the frittata cool slightly before serving with fresh salad leaves.

Employ a shallow depth of field, focusing on a central slice of frittata, blurring the foreground and background elements for a dreamy effect.  The overall mood should be inviting, fresh, and appetizing. Include a linen napkin and vintage cutlery for a touch of elegance.

recipes.name: Baby Pak Choy with Chili and Black Bean Sauce
ingredients: 3cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and cut into matchsticks
1 long fresh red chili, halved, deseeded, and thinly sliced
directions: Step 1: Heat a wok over high heat.
Step 2: Add the olive oil and heat until just smoking.
Step 3: Add the ginger, garlic, and chili to the wok and stir-fry for 1 minute, or until aromatic.
Step 4: Add the baby pak choy, chicken stock, black bean sauce, and sherry to the wok.
Step 5: Cook, stirring, for 3-5 minutes, or until the pak choy wilts and the sauce reduces slightly.
Step 6: Transfer the pak choy to a serving bowl and drizzle with the sauce.

recipes.name: Hoisin-Glazed Lamb with Pak Choy and Steamed Rice
ingredients: 2 bunches baby pak choy, quartered lengthwise
directions: Step 1: In a large glass or ceramic bowl, combine the hoisin sauce and dry sherry.
Step 2: Add the lamb eye of loin to the bowl and turn to coat thoroughly with the hoisin-sherry mixture.
Step 3: Set the lamb aside to marinate for 5 minutes.
Step 4: Meanwhile, lightly spray a non-stick wok or large frying pan with olive oil spray and heat over medium heat.
Step 5: Add the finely chopped garlic and ginger to the hot wok and stir-fry for 1 minute, or until softened.
Step 6: Add the quartered pak choy, chicken stock, and oyster sauce to the wok.
Step 7: Cook, stirring frequently, for 5 minutes, or until the pak choy wilts and the sauce reduces slightly.
Step 8: Taste the pak choy mixture and season with ground white pepper as needed.
Step 9: Preheat a barbecue grill or chargrill to medium-high heat and lightly spray with olive oil spray.
Step 10: Add the marinated lamb to the preheated grill and cook for 3-4 minutes per side for medium, or until cooked to your liking.
Step 11: Transfer the cooked lamb to a plate, cover with foil, and set aside to rest for 5 minutes.
Step 12: Thickly slice the rested lamb diagonally.
Step 13: Divide the steamed rice, pak choy mixture, and sliced lamb among serving bowls.
Step 14: Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Pork and Sweet Corn Noodle Soup with Pak Choy
ingredients: 1 large bunch baby pak choy, trimmed and leaves separated
1 tsp Massel Salt Reduced Chicken Stock Powder
3cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and cut into matchsticks
directions: Step 1: Cook noodles according to package directions until al dente. Drain and divide among serving bowls.
Step 2: While the noodles are cooking, prepare the broth. In a large saucepan, combine the boiling water, chicken stock powder, and ginger. Bring to a boil over high heat.
Step 3: Reduce heat to low and add the sherry, soy sauce, and sugar. Simmer for 2 minutes.
Step 4: Add the corn kernels to the saucepan and simmer for another 2 minutes.
Step 5: Add the thinly sliced pork and pak choy stems to the soup. Simmer for 1-2 minutes, or until the pork is cooked through and the pak choy stems are tender-crisp.
Step 6: Add the pak choy leaves and simmer for another minute until wilted.
Step 7: Ladle the hot soup over the noodles in the serving bowls. Garnish with sliced shallots.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Pork and Sweet Corn Noodle Soup with Pak Choy in a rustic, off-white bowl.  Steam gently rises from the vibrant broth, showcasing the tender pork slices, bright corn kernels, and vibrant green pak choy.  Natural, diffused lighting emphasizes the textures.  A dark wooden backdrop and a simple linen napkin enhance the mood.  Shallow depth of field focuses on the pork and corn, blurring the background slightly for a cozy and inviting feel.  Garnish with a few sprigs of fresh cilantro for a pop of color.

scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today we're making a comforting and flavorful Pork and Sweet Corn Noodle Soup with Pak Choy. It's quick, easy, and perfect for a weeknight meal.

scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: Chang's Long Life Noodles, fresh baby pak choy, corn kernels, and thinly sliced pork fillet.  We'll also use some pantry staples like ginger, sherry, soy sauce, and chicken stock powder.

scenes.image_prompt: Pot of boiling water with noodles being added.
scenes.voice_over: First, cook 125g of Chang's Long Life Noodles according to package directions until al dente. Drain and set aside.

scenes.image_prompt: Large saucepan with boiling water, chicken stock powder, and ginger.
scenes.voice_over: In a large saucepan, combine 1.5 liters of boiling water, 1 teaspoon of Massel Salt Reduced Chicken Stock Powder, and matchsticks of ginger. Bring this to a boil.

scenes.image_prompt: The broth simmering with sherry, soy sauce, and sugar.
scenes.voice_over: Reduce the heat to low, add 2 tablespoons of dry sherry, 2 teaspoons of salt-reduced soy sauce, and 1 teaspoon of caster sugar. Simmer for 2 minutes to let the flavors meld.

scenes.image_prompt: Adding corn kernels to the simmering broth.
scenes.voice_over: Add 1 cup of fresh corn kernels to the saucepan and simmer for another 2 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Adding pork and pak choy stems to the soup.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add 400g of thinly sliced pork fillet and the pak choy stems to the soup.  Simmer for 1-2 minutes, or until the pork is cooked through and the stems are tender-crisp.

scenes.image_prompt: Adding pak choy leaves to the soup.
scenes.voice_over: Add the pak choy leaves and simmer for just another minute until they wilt beautifully.

scenes.image_prompt: Ladling the soup over noodles in serving bowls and garnishing with shallots.
scenes.voice_over: Ladle the hot soup over the cooked noodles. Garnish with sliced shallots.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of a finished bowl of soup with chopsticks, ready to be enjoyed.
scenes.voice_over: This soup is packed with flavor and nutrients, with around 400 calories, 30 grams of protein, 45 grams of carbs, and 15 grams of fat per serving. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer broth, use homemade chicken stock instead of stock powder.
If you don't have dry sherry, you can substitute with Shaoxing rice wine or mirin.

recipes.name: Seared Beef with Pak Choi, Mushrooms, and Rice Noodles
ingredients: 1 thumb-sized piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely sliced
1 fresh red chili, deseeded and finely sliced
directions: Step 1: Cook the rice noodles according to package directions. Set aside.
Step 2: Rub the beef sirloin with olive oil, cumin, and salt.
Step 3: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Sear the beef on all sides until browned.
Step 4: Add the sliced red onion, ginger, and chili to the skillet. Cook for 2 minutes.
Step 5: Add the mushrooms, chicken stock, and pak choi to the skillet.
Step 6: Drain the cooked noodles and add them to the skillet. Stir to combine.
Step 7: Slice the seared beef and arrange it over the noodles and pak choi. Pour the broth from the skillet over the dish. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Ginger Sweet Tofu with Pak Choi
ingredients: 250g firm tofu, drained and cut into bite-sized cubes
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Tofu: Gently prick the tofu with a toothpick. Cut the drained tofu into bite-sized cubes. In a bowl, combine the grated ginger, dark soy sauce, light soy sauce, and brown sugar. Add the tofu cubes to the marinade and toss gently. Set aside to marinate for 10-15 minutes.

Step 2: Stir-fry Pak Choi: Heat a wok over high heat and add half of the groundnut oil. Once the oil starts to smoke, add the sliced ginger and stir-fry for a few seconds. Add the pak choi leaves and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes. Add a splash of water to create steam and cook for another 2 minutes, until the leaves wilt and the stems are tender-crisp. Season with salt and transfer to a serving dish.

Step 3: Stir-fry Tofu: Rinse the wok and return it to high heat. Add the remaining groundnut oil. Once hot, add the marinated tofu, reserving the marinade. Stir-fry for 5-10 minutes, browning evenly on all sides. Season with rice wine and rice vinegar. Pour in the reserved marinade, bring to a simmer, and reduce slightly. Sprinkle with chili flakes and toss well.
Step 4: Serve: Spoon the tofu over the pak choi and serve immediately with cooked jasmine rice, if desired.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture ginger sweet tofu with pak choi on a dark slate backdrop. Style the crispy tofu and vibrant green pak choi over a bed of fluffy jasmine rice. Garnish with grated ginger and chili flakes. Use a 45-degree angle, shallow depth of field focusing on the tofu's texture, and soft, diffused lighting to create a warm, inviting mood. Incorporate subtle reflections and highlights to showcase the sauce's glossiness. Include chopsticks and a rustic linen napkin as props.

recipes.name: Spicy Beetroot, Pak Choi, and Marinated Eggs
ingredients: 4 medium Beetroot, peeled and cut into 8 wedges
directions: Step 1: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Gently place the eggs in the boiling water and cook for 6 minutes. Immediately transfer the eggs to a bowl of ice water to stop cooking. Once cooled, peel the eggs.

Step 2: In a bowl, whisk together the sake, soy sauce, and mirin. Add the peeled eggs to the marinade, ensuring they are fully submerged. Cover the bowl with a plate or lid and refrigerate for at least 3 hours, or preferably overnight.
Step 3: Preheat oven to 200°C (180°C fan/gas mark 6). Toss the beetroot wedges with 1 tablespoon of olive oil and spread them in a single layer on a large baking tray. Roast for 50 minutes.

Step 4: In a small bowl, combine the remaining soy sauce, gochujang, and chili oil (if using). Remove the beetroot from the oven and coat with the sauce mixture. Return to the oven and roast for another 5-10 minutes, or until caramelized.

Step 5: Arrange the roasted beetroot and halved pak choi on a serving platter. Place a marinated egg cut in half alongside the vegetables. Sprinkle with sesame seeds and drizzle with sriracha to taste.

recipes.name: Five-Spice Pork with Roasted Pumpkin and Pak Choy
ingredients: 500g butternut pumpkin, peeled, deseeded, and thinly sliced
2 bunches baby pak choy, washed and quartered
directions: Step 1: In a glass or ceramic bowl, combine the soy sauce, sweet chili sauce, five-spice powder, ginger, and garlic.
Step 2: Add the pork medallions to the marinade and toss to coat. Set aside.
Step 3: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Toss the sliced pumpkin with a drizzle of oil and season with salt and pepper. Spread in a single layer on a baking sheet.
Step 4: Roast the pumpkin for 15-20 minutes, or until tender and slightly caramelized.
Step 5: Heat half the peanut oil in a large non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat.
Step 6: Remove the pork from the marinade and reserve the marinade.
Step 7: Add half the pork to the hot pan and cook for 2-3 minutes per side, or until cooked through.
Step 8: Transfer the cooked pork to a plate and repeat with the remaining oil and pork.
Step 9: Add the reserved marinade to the pan and cook for 1 minute, or until heated through.
Step 10: In a separate pan, quickly stir-fry the pak choy with the remaining oil for 2 minutes until wilted.
Step 11: Divide the roasted pumpkin and stir-fried pak choy among serving plates. Top with the cooked pork.
Step 12: Drizzle the heated marinade over the pork and vegetables.
Step 13: Serve with lime wedges, if desired.

recipes.name: Sesame Garlic Beef with Pak Choy
ingredients: 500 g beef rump steak, fat trimmed, thinly sliced against the grain
1 white onion, cut into thin wedges
1 red bell pepper, seeded, thinly sliced
directions: Step 1: In a shallow dish, combine the crushed garlic, sesame oil, and 1 tablespoon of dry sherry.
Step 2: Add the sliced beef to the marinade, ensuring it's fully coated.
Step 3: Cover the dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Step 4: In a small bowl, whisk together the cornflour and cold water until smooth. Stir in the soy sauce and remaining sherry.
Step 5: Heat a large wok or skillet over high heat and lightly coat with oil.
Step 6: Stir-fry one-third of the marinated beef for 2 minutes, or until browned. Remove from wok and set aside.
Step 7: Repeat step 6 with the remaining two batches of beef.
Step 8: Add a little more oil to the wok, if needed, and stir-fry the onion wedges for 2 minutes.
Step 9: Add the sliced bell pepper and stir-fry for 1 minute.
Step 10: Add the pak choy leaves and stir-fry for 1 minute, or until slightly wilted.
Step 11: Return the cooked beef to the wok.
Step 12: Pour the soy sauce mixture over the beef and vegetables.
Step 13: Stir-fry for 1-2 minutes, or until heated through.
Step 14: Serve the beef and vegetable mixture over steamed rice and garnish with toasted sesame seeds.

recipes.name: Crunchy Pak Choy and Bean Sprout Salad with Chili-Lime Dressing
ingredients: 1/2 small red bell pepper, thinly sliced
12 (200g) baby pak choy, leaves separated and halved

directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, combine the carrot, bean sprouts, red bell pepper, wombok, and pak choy.

scenes.voice_over: For our zesty chili-lime dressing, we'll use fresh lime juice, a vibrant red chili, fish sauce for umami, brown sugar for a touch of sweetness, and sesame oil for a nutty aroma.

scenes.voice_over: In a large bowl, combine the carrot, bean sprouts, red bell pepper, wombok, and pak choy.  Give it a quick toss.

scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, whisk together the lime juice, chopped chili, fish sauce, brown sugar, and sesame oil until the sugar is dissolved.

scenes.image_prompt: Pouring the chili-lime dressing over the salad in the large bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Pour the dressing over the salad and toss gently to coat all the vegetables evenly.

recipes.name: Pork and Plum Stir-Fry with Pak Choy and Rice Noodles
ingredients: 2 small bunches baby pak choy, leaves separated and stems coarsely chopped
1 brown onion, halved and thinly sliced
directions: Step 1: Prepare the rice noodles according to package directions.
Step 2: Heat a wok over high heat. Add half the olive oil and heat until shimmering.
Step 3: Add half the pork strips to the wok and stir-fry for 2 minutes, or until lightly browned. Transfer to a plate.
Step 4: Repeat with the remaining pork strips.
Step 5: Add the remaining olive oil to the wok. Add the onion, carrot, and ginger. Stir-fry for 2 minutes, or until the onion softens.
Step 6: Add the mushrooms and pak choy stems to the wok. Stir-fry for 1 minute.
Step 7: Add the cooked noodles, browned pork, pak choy leaves, and plum sauce to the wok.
Step 8: Stir-fry for 2 minutes, or until the sauce thickens slightly.
Step 9: Divide the stir-fry among serving bowls and garnish with fresh coriander.

recipes.name: Slow Cooker Pork Ramen
ingredients: 4 cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated
directions: Step 1: In a large jug or bowl, whisk together the chicken stock, soy sauce, mirin, brown sugar, and miso paste until the sugar and miso have dissolved.
Step 2: Place the crushed garlic, grated ginger, pork steaks, and mushrooms in the slow cooker.
Step 3: Pour the stock mixture over the ingredients in the slow cooker and stir well. Cover and cook on low for 6 hours, or until the pork is tender and falling apart.
Step 4: Stir the lime juice into the slow cooker mixture, breaking up any large pieces of pork. Check the seasoning and adjust if necessary.
Step 5: Cook the ramen noodles according to package directions, adding the pak choi for the last minute of cooking time. Drain.
Step 6: Divide the noodles and pak choi among 4 deep bowls. Ladle the ramen mixture over the noodles and pak choi, ensuring the pork and mushrooms are evenly distributed.
Step 7: Garnish with sliced spring onions and top each bowl with a halved soft-boiled egg, if desired.

Include a halved lime wedge on the side.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the pork and mushrooms in the foreground, creating a warm, inviting mood.  Use rustic wooden chopsticks and a dark ceramic spoon as props.

recipes.name: Thai-Style Chicken Fried Rice
ingredients: 1 red onion, halved and thinly sliced
1 long fresh red chili, halved, seeded, and minced
1 bunch pak choy, stems and leaves separated
directions: Step 1: Heat half of the peanut oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat.
Step 2: Add the sliced red onion and stir-fry for 1 minute, or until softened.
Step 3: Add the minced garlic and chili and stir-fry for another minute, until fragrant.
Step 4: Add the pak choy stems and halved grape tomatoes. Stir-fry for 3 minutes, or until softened.
Step 5: Transfer the cooked vegetables to a bowl and set aside.
Step 6: Heat the remaining peanut oil in the wok.
Step 7: Add the cooled cooked rice to the wok and stir-fry for 3-4 minutes, until heated through.
Step 8: Make a well in the center of the rice.
Step 9: Pour the whisked eggs into the well and cook, stirring occasionally, for 1-2 minutes, or until almost set.
Step 10: Add the pak choy leaves, fish sauce, and shredded cooked chicken to the wok.
Step 11: Toss everything together to combine.
Step 12: Return the cooked vegetable mixture (onion, garlic, chili, pak choy stems, and tomatoes) to the wok.
Step 13: Stir-fry for another minute or two, until heated through and well combined.

recipes.name: Japanese Udon Noodle Soup with Tofu, Bok Choy, and Miso
ingredients: 1 small bunch baby bok choy, trimmed and separated into leaves and stems
400g Japanese-style teriyaki tofu, cut into 1cm cubes
directions: Step 1: Place udon noodles in a heatproof bowl and cover with boiling water. Let stand for 1-2 minutes, or until tender. Separate noodles with a fork and drain.
Step 2: In a large saucepan, combine miso paste and 6 cups of cold water over medium-high heat. Cook, stirring, for 2 minutes, or until the paste has dissolved.
Step 3: Cover the saucepan and bring the miso broth to a boil.
Step 4: Thinly slice the bok choy stems and cut the leaves in half.
Step 5: Add the bok choy stems and leaves, tofu cubes, and sliced mushrooms to the boiling miso broth.
Step 6: Cook for 2 minutes, or until the bok choy leaves have just wilted.
Step 7: Divide the cooked udon noodles among serving bowls.
Step 8: Ladle the hot miso mixture with tofu, bok choy, and mushrooms over the noodles.
Step 9: Garnish each bowl with sliced green onions and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Soy-Ginger Chargrilled Beef with Pak Choy and Steamed Rice
directions: Step 1: In a shallow glass or ceramic dish, combine the soy sauce, peanut oil, grated fresh ginger, and honey.
Step 2: Add the beef steaks to the marinade, turning to coat thoroughly.
Step 3: Cover the dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 20 minutes to marinate.
Step 4: Preheat a chargrill to medium-high heat.
Step 5: Remove the beef from the marinade, reserving the marinade in a small saucepan.
Step 6: Grill the steaks for 4-5 minutes per side for medium, or until cooked to your liking.
Step 7: Transfer the cooked steaks to a plate, cover with foil, and let rest for 5 minutes.
Step 8: While the steaks rest, bring the reserved marinade to a boil over high heat.
Step 9: Cook the marinade for 1-2 minutes, or until slightly thickened.
Step 10: Place the halved pak choy on the chargrill and cook for 2 minutes per side, or until tender and slightly charred.
Step 11: To serve, spoon steamed rice onto plates, top with the rested beef steaks, drizzle with the thickened soy-ginger sauce, and serve alongside the grilled pak choy.

recipes.name: Lower-GI Spicy Stir-Fried Prawns with Pak Choy and Green Beans
ingredients: 1 long green chili, deseeded and finely chopped
7cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and grated
20 (500g) green prawns, peeled (tails intact) and deveined
200g baby pak choy, leaves and stems separated, stems chopped
150g green beans, trimmed and halved diagonally
directions: Step 1: Heat a wok over high heat.
Step 2: Add half of the peanut oil and swirl to coat the wok.
Step 3: Add the chili, ginger, garlic, and prawns to the wok.
Step 4: Stir-fry for 2 minutes, or until the prawns are pink and cooked through.
Step 5: Transfer the prawns to a bowl and cover to keep warm.
Step 6: Heat the remaining peanut oil in the wok.
Step 7: Add the green onions, pak choy stems, and green beans.
Step 8: Stir-fry for 4 minutes, or until the beans are just tender.
Step 9: Return the prawns to the wok.
Step 10: Add the rice noodles, soy sauce, mirin, and pak choy leaves.
Step 11: Stir-fry for 1 to 2 minutes, or until heated through.
Step 12: Serve immediately.

Focus on the glistening prawns nestled amongst the vibrant green vegetables and rice noodles.  Use dark slate or wood backdrop with subtle Asian-inspired props like chopsticks and a small ceramic bowl.  Soft, directional lighting should highlight the texture of the prawns and vegetables.  Shallow depth of field with the prawns in sharp focus, creating a sense of freshness and warmth. Garnish with a sprinkle of chopped green onions and chili flakes.  Shoot from a slightly elevated angle to showcase the colorful mix of ingredients.

scenes.voice_over: Start by heating your wok over high heat. Add half the peanut oil and swirl it around to coat the wok evenly.

scenes.voice_over: Now add the chopped chili, grated ginger, and crushed garlic. Stir-fry for a few seconds until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: Prawns being added to the wok, stir-frying until pink and cooked through.
scenes.voice_over: Add the prawns and stir-fry for about 2 minutes until they turn pink and are fully cooked. Be careful not to overcook them.

scenes.image_prompt: Cooked prawns being transferred to a bowl and covered.
scenes.voice_over: Transfer the cooked prawns to a bowl and cover to keep them warm.

scenes.image_prompt: Green onions, pak choy stems, and green beans being stir-fried in the wok.
scenes.voice_over: Add the remaining peanut oil to the wok. Toss in the green onions, pak choy stems, and green beans. Stir-fry for about 4 minutes until they're tender-crisp.

scenes.image_prompt: Prawns being returned to the wok with the vegetables.
scenes.voice_over: Return the prawns to the wok with the vegetables.

scenes.image_prompt: Noodles, soy sauce, mirin, and pak choy leaves being added to the wok, stir-frying until heated through.
scenes.voice_over: Add the rice noodles, soy sauce, mirin, and pak choy leaves. Stir-fry for another minute or two until everything is heated through and the sauce is well combined.

recipes.name: Colorful Tofu Stir-Fry
ingredients: 1 small pak choi, separated leaves and stems, chopped
directions: Step 1: Heat the chili-infused oil in a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat.
Step 2: Add the diced onion and bell pepper strips to the wok and stir-fry for 3-4 minutes until slightly softened.
Step 3: Add the minced garlic and diced tomatoes to the wok, and continue to stir-fry for another 2 minutes.
Step 4: Add the diced tofu to the wok. Sprinkle with cumin and rosemary. Stir-fry for 5-7 minutes, until the tofu is lightly browned.
Step 5: Add the chopped pak choi stems to the wok and stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Step 6: Add the pak choi leaves to the wok and stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes, or until the leaves have wilted.
Step 7: Season with salt to taste.
Step 8: Serve the stir-fry hot, optionally with brown rice or noodles.

recipes.name: Chilli and Lemongrass Beef with Pak Choy and Steamed Rice
ingredients: 1 stalk lemongrass, white part only, finely chopped
1 large red chili, halved, deseeded, and finely chopped
3 cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
4 beef sirloin steaks (about 125g each), excess fat trimmed
2 bunches baby pak choy, ends trimmed
directions: Step 1: Combine lemongrass, chili, and ginger in a food processor and process until finely chopped.
Step 2: Add the chopped coriander, rice wine vinegar, fish sauce, and sugar to the food processor. Process until well combined.
Step 3: Place the beef steaks in a shallow glass or ceramic dish.
Step 4: Pour the lemongrass mixture over the beef and stir to coat.
Step 5: Cover the dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes to marinate.
Step 6: Heat a large chargrill pan or grill over high heat.
Step 7: Lightly grease the grill with olive oil spray.
Step 8: Remove the beef from the marinade and discard the marinade.
Step 9: Grill the steaks for 3 minutes per side for medium-rare, or until cooked to your liking.
Step 10: Transfer the cooked steaks to a plate, cover loosely with foil, and let rest for 5 minutes.
Step 11: While the beef rests, cook the pak choy in a saucepan of boiling water for 30 seconds, or until just wilted and bright green. Drain well.
Step 12: Thickly slice the rested beef across the grain.
Step 13: Divide the steamed rice among serving plates.
Step 14: Top the rice with the pak choy, sliced beef, and fresh coriander leaves to serve.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture Chilli and Lemongrass Beef with steamed rice and Pak Choy in a rustic, dark-toned setting.  Focus on the glistening beef, highlighting its texture. Arrange pak choy artfully around the beef, showcasing its vibrant green. Garnish with fresh coriander and sliced red chili. Use a shallow depth of field, focusing on the beef, with soft, diffused lighting to create a warm, inviting mood. A slightly overhead angle should showcase the dish's components. Incorporate natural textures like wood or slate.

scenes.voice_over: Combine the marinade ingredients in a food processor until finely chopped.  Place the beef steaks in a dish and pour the marinade over, ensuring they are fully coated. Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes. This allows the beef to absorb all those wonderful flavors.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of beef steaks grilling on a hot grill pan, with smoke and char marks visible.
scenes.voice_over: Heat your grill or grill pan to high heat. Lightly grease with oil and grill the steaks for about 3 minutes per side for medium-rare, or longer for your preferred doneness.

scenes.voice_over: Once cooked, transfer the steaks to a plate, cover loosely with foil, and let them rest for 5 minutes. This allows the juices to redistribute, resulting in a more tender and flavorful steak.

scenes.voice_over: Once rested, slice the beef thickly against the grain.

scenes.voice_over: Serve the dish by dividing the steamed rice among plates. Top with the blanched pak choy, sliced beef, and garnish with fresh coriander leaves.  This dish is around 400-450 calories per serving with about 30-35 grams of protein.

cooking_tips: For a spicier marinade, add another chili or a pinch of chili flakes.
If you don't have a grill pan, you can use a large skillet.
Don't overcrowd the pan when grilling the steaks. Cook in batches if necessary to ensure even browning.
Let the beef rest to allow the juices to redistribute, resulting in a more tender steak.

recipes.name: Stir-fried Asian Greens with Shiitake Mushrooms
ingredients: 100 grams fresh shiitake mushrooms, thinly sliced
1 bunch baby pak choy, trimmed, leaves separated, stems cut from leaves
1 (425 gram) can baby corn spears, drained
directions: Step 1: Heat the peanut oil in a large frying pan or wok over medium-high heat.
Step 2: Add the crushed garlic and grated ginger to the pan and stir-fry for 30 seconds, or until aromatic.
Step 3: Add the sliced shiitake mushrooms and stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Step 4: Add the pak choy stems and stir-fry for 1 minute.
Step 5: Add the pak choy leaves, baby bok choy, drained baby corn spears, oyster sauce, and soy sauce to the pan.
Step 6: Toss the ingredients to combine.
Step 7: Add the water and reduce the heat to low.
Step 8: Cover the pan and cook for 2 minutes, or until the vegetables are just tender.
Step 9: Serve immediately.

Use dark wood or slate as a background, accented by natural linen and chopsticks. Garnish with toasted sesame seeds and chopped scallions. Backlighting and subtle rim lighting should highlight the steam and texture of the dish.  A slightly overhead, 45-degree angle will best showcase the colorful ingredients.

scenes.voice_over: Craving a healthy and delicious weeknight meal?  This Stir-fried Asian Greens with Shiitake Mushrooms recipe is ready in minutes and bursting with flavor!

scenes.voice_over: Add two crushed cloves of garlic and two teaspoons of grated ginger. Stir-fry for about 30 seconds until fragrant.

scenes.voice_over: Now, add 100 grams of sliced shiitake mushrooms and stir-fry for two minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: The remaining vegetables, sauces, and water are added to the pan.  Show the tossing motion.

scenes.voice_over: Add two tablespoons of water, reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for two minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.

If you don't have oyster sauce, you can substitute with hoisin sauce or a mixture of soy sauce and brown sugar.

recipes.name: Quick & Fiery Red Thai Chicken Curry
ingredients: 100g fine green beans, trimmed and halved
1 teaspoon soy sauce or fish sauce
directions: Step 1: Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan or wok over medium heat. Add the red curry paste and cook, stirring constantly, for 1 minute until fragrant.
Step 2: Add the sliced chicken and onion to the pan. Cook for 3-5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the chicken is lightly browned.
Step 3: Add the green beans and chicken stock to the pan. Bring to a simmer and cook for 3 minutes.
Step 4: Add the pak choi leaves to the pan and stir to combine.
Step 5: Pour in the coconut milk, reduce the heat to low, and simmer gently for 5-7 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the vegetables are tender.
Step 6: Stir in the soy sauce or fish sauce and season to taste.
Step 7: While the curry is simmering, cook the basmati rice according to package directions.
Step 8: To serve, fluff the cooked rice and divide it among bowls. Top with the red chicken curry and garnish with fresh coriander and lime wedges.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant, close-up shot of Quick & Fiery Red Thai Chicken Curry in a shallow, dark-grey bowl, garnished with fresh coriander.  Use a slightly overhead angle, showcasing the rich red curry, tender chicken, and green vegetables.  Employ soft, diffused natural light to highlight the textures.  A dark wood background and a linen napkin subtly draped nearby add depth.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the chicken and sauce, creates a warm, inviting mood.
